newsitem.title: USA: US OPTIONS FOCUS/IBM volume up after split.
newsitem.headline: US OPTIONS FOCUS/IBM volume up after split.

text.p: A two-for-one stock split in International Business Machines Corp took effect Wednesday and drew heavy interest to both the stock and the options, traders said.
In early afternoon activity, IBM was the third most active stock on the New York Stock Exchange, with more than 3.8 million shares changing hands. Consolidated volume topped 5.2 million shares.
The stock gained 1-5/8 to 91-1/4.

"I think you'll see a significant increase in IBM volume because of the split," said Jon Najarian, president of Mercury Trading, the designated primary market maker for IBM options. "There are just more players able to trade $3 and $4 options than there are $6 and $8."
The IBM June 92-1/2 call traded more than 8,300 contracts, making it the most active. It was trading at 2-3/4.
The June 90 call traded about 7,640 contracts and the June 87-1/2 call traded more than 5,200.
Among puts, the June 85 was most active, with turnover of rougly 1,380 contracts.
Trading was also heavy in the IBM July calls, led by the 95, which traded more than 3,400 contracts.
"After the split, we've had some people closing out positions and some putting on new ones," said Rod Jamieson at Everen Securities.

Elsewhere, Bay Networks Inc options were fairly busy as the stock rallied after a SoundView Financial Group analyst raised his rating on the stock to short-term buy from hold and increased fiscal 1997 and 1998 earnings estimates.
The analyst maintained a long-term hold.
Bay Networks shares were up two at 24-3/4.
"When they talk on high techs, everyone listens," Najarian said, referring to SoundView.
He said an institution was a big buyer of the Bay Networks June and July 25 calls.

The June 25 call traded 3,525 contracts and the July 25 call traded about 1,680. Other actives included the June 22-1/2 call, with turnover of 1,235 contracts, and the June 20 call, with turnover of 875.
The most active put was the June 25, which traded roughly 390 contracts.
Traders said overall, individual equity options were quiet.
"It's very quiet," one options trader said. "I think a lot of people are just waiting to see what happens with this market."
He added that technology stock options were active even when the rest of the market was quiet.
"We were a little busy yesterday, but today is much quieter," another trader said.
